awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE Incubator: An Interdisciplinary Network in Hawai'i to Develop, Support, and Assess Pathways into STEM Through Research Experiences in Marine Science (REMS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of the Research Experiences in Marine Science (REMS) Research Coordination Network incubator project is to build and strengthen science pathways through the development of cumulative, culturally responsive, course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) in marine science in Hawai‘i. This project will coordinate an interdisciplinary gathering of communities that seek to empower students from groups historically excluded from STEM in Hawai‘i, with particular focus on Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander populations. University of Hawai'i (Hawai'i) students, and in particular Native Hawaiian students, face high rates of attrition and low representation in STEM academic and career pathways, but place-based research experiences that are culturally grounded, relevant, responsible, and sustainable may promote persistence.

This network seeks to foster a culturally and professionally diverse community of marine science researchers and educators by conducting workshops to facilitate knowledge exchanges among network partners and outline network needs and creating and piloting novel modules for a marine science CURE. The network activities will center around the REMS Summer Program, a place-based CURE designed to support Hawaiʻi students (including high representation of Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander students) as they transition into undergraduate STEM pathways. Professional development workshops that highlight place-based practices, laulima (community work/service) days at community partner sites, and a student research symposium hosted during the REMS program will be used to promote equitable and reciprocal relationships amongst network participants and REMS community partners. This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for STEM Education, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange/finalreport/).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to enhance undergraduate biology education by fostering collaboration and sharing resources among marine science educators, professional researchers, and resource managers. This network represented 12 departments across three universities and one two-year institution, state and federal partnerships, and three non-profit aquaculture and maritime organizations. Hosted at the Hawaiʻi Institute of Marine Biology (HIMB), a research unit of the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa, the project sought to develop a network to build and strengthen undergraduate STEM pathways. Central to this effort was the development of a cumulative, immersive, course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) called REMS (Research Experiences in Marine Science). Through workshops, civic workdays, site exchanges, and an immersive summer research course, the project helped build and strengthen a sustainable network for advancing marine science education.

Three professional development workshops were successfully conducted, each focusing on a distinct theme:

1.   Reef System CURE (Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience) – This workshop emphasized developing immersive curricula and authentic teaching strategies tailored for students in Hawaiʻi with an emphasis on near-shore reef systems.

2.   Incorporating Civic Literacy in Science Education – Participants explored methods to integrate discussions on local resource policy within the science classroom.

3.   Weaving Vernacular Language and Perspectives into Research Experiences – This session focused on embedding student perspectives and language into undergraduate research.

The workshops brought together a group of participants that spanned across academic and social groups including research faculty, graduate and undergraduate students, local knowledge stewards, and resource managers, and facilitated knowledge-sharing and collaborative curriculum development, directly impacting marine science education at the undergraduate level.

Two new teaching modules were piloted:

1.   Herbivorous Fish Behavioral Responses to Sedimentation: Developed in collaboration with the Fish Resilience Lab at HIMB and REMS graduate teaching alumni, this module guides students through laboratory investigations of foraging behaviors in Hawaiian coral reef fishes exposed to varying levels of sedimentation. The goal is to simulate the effects of urban runoff on near-shore reef systems.

2.   Strengthening Civic Connections through Environmental and Epistemological Stewardship: Led by network members with backgrounds in land policy, this module targets early undergraduates interested in marine STEM and conservation. It covers topics such as State and Federal constitutional policies affecting research practices and emphasizes respect for Native Hawaiian rights regarding land and sea stewardship.

In June 2024, the network facilitated a site exchange between the REMS network and members of the Pacific/Polar Opportunities to Learn, Advance, and Research Indigenous Systems (POLARIS) Network and the Indigenous STEAM Collaborative. Representatives from POLARIS and Indigenous STEAM visited HIMB during the first week of the REMS program and actively participated alongside the students. Later that month, the project PI and a senior staff member visited Michigan to observe an Indigenous STEAM summer program hosted by the Little Traverse Bay Band of Odawa Indians. These site exchanges enabled curriculum developers and educators to observe and adopt novel research techniques and pedagogical approaches. These exchanges helped bridge the gap between research and teaching, enriching the curriculum with current marine science research findings.

During the summer of 2024, the network also hosted the REMS early-college research intensive at HIMB that included 25 undergraduate students, five graduate student instructors, and a range of mentors, including postdoctoral researchers, faculty from both two- and four-year institutions, resource managers, and community leaders. Both undergraduate and graduate student participants earned college credit (4 credits of marine biology lecture and lab for the undergraduates, and 4 credits of teaching seminar and practicum for the graduate instructors) and disseminated their work at a student research symposium. This event encouraged the development of scientific communication skills and highlighted the importance of research experiences in undergraduate education.

Broader impacts were also implicitly emphasized through site visits with community partners, such as Waikalua Aquatic Institute, Paepae o Heʻeia, and Kānehūnāmoku Voyaging Academy, who study and manage maritime and estuarine resources independently and support education in partnership with projects at HIMB. Three service-work days were coordinated, allowing participants to engage in hands-on activities such as habitat restoration, data collection, and public outreach. These events not only enhanced practical learning experiences for students but also fostered a sense of civic involvement and stewardship. Additionally, network members published an article in CBE: Life Sciences Education describing latent factors in undergraduate student learning gains in marine biology after participating in REMS.

Regular feedback from participants was crucial for refining workshop content and ensuring that the teaching modules met the needs of educators and students alike. Analysis of network participant surveys and discussions suggested lessons relevant to early-college STEM opportunities and sustaining intellectual networks, such as the establishment and support of multi-tiered mentoring scaffolds, emphasis on student lived experiences, and earlier exposure to marine science to encourage persistence in STEM pathways.
